items.title: Large-scale audiometric phenotyping identifies distinct genes and pathways involved in hearing loss subtypes
items.author: Britt I. Drögemöller
items.content: Computational phenotyping of audiometric data reveals differences in the genetic pathways involved in sensory and metabolic hearing loss.

items.title: Irisin inhibits dopaminergic neuron lactate metabolism and repairs mitochondrial function to alleviate Parkinson’s disease by activating SIRT1 signaling pathway
items.author: Rujia Xie
items.content: Irisin alleviates Parkinson’s disease symptoms by activating the SIRT1 signaling pathway, inhibiting dopaminergic neuron lactate metabolism, and repairing mitochondrial function.

items.title: Transcriptomic response analysis of rubber tree saplings to water-deficit stress at single-cell resolution
items.author: Jin Liu
items.content: Single-cell profiling in rubber tree saplings to water-deficit stress identifies seven bark cell types and ABA-mediated drought responses, including uniform ABF2/3/4 induction.

items.title: Spatial development of brain networks during the first six postnatal months
items.author: Armin Iraji
items.content: Longitudinal rs-fMRI (n = 74) charts rapid spatial maturation of infant brain networks over the first 6 months: greater spatial similarity, tighter voxel engagement, and network-specific gains in strength, size, and centroids.

items.title: The Chromosome 19 miRNA cluster guards trophoblasts against overacting innate immunity
items.author: Yoel Sadovsky
items.content: Silenced expression of Chromosome 19 MicroRNA Cluster (C19MC) in human trophoblasts lines and trophoblast stem cells activates cellular innate immune response and increased Toll-like receptor 3-mediated sensitivity to the viral RNA mimic poly(I:C).

items.title: Unveiling and stratifying cell cycle-dependent drug efficacy using a single-cell PLOM-CON approach with correlation anomaly and presage protein signals
items.author: Fumi Kano
items.content: Single-cell covariation network analysis sheds light on cell cycle-dependent drug efficacy and identifies presage protein signals that predict future cell cycle arrest.

items.title: RECKLEEN is a lambda Red/CRISPR-Cas9 based single plasmid platform for enhanced genome editing in Klebsiella pneumoniae
items.author: Anke Becker
items.content: RECKLEEN, a CRISPR–recombineering platform, enables efficient, flexible, and scalable genome editing in multidrug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae, facilitating precise deletions, point mutations, and integrations across diverse clinical strains.

items.title: On the replicability of diffusion weighted MRI-based brain-behavior models
items.author: Tamas Spisak
items.content: Structural connectome-based predictive models can yield replicable brain–behavior associations with moderate samples in several cases, but large datasets remain key for explainability, bias control, fairness, and generalizability.
